Title.evidence: The aim of this RCT was to assess the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of nail bed repair with fingernail replacement/substitution compared with repair without fingernail replacement.

Trial_Design.evidence: A two-arm 1 : 1 parallel-group open multicentre superiority RCT was performed across 20 secondary-care hospitals in the UK.

Participants.evidence: 451 children presenting with a suspected nail bed injury were recruited between July 2018 and July 2019.

Intervention.evidence: 224 were allocated to the nail-discarded arm, and 227 to the nail-replaced arm.

Objective.evidence: The aim of this RCT was to assess the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of nail bed repair with fingernail replacement/substitution compared with repair without fingernail replacement.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The co-primary outcomes were surgical-site infection at around 7 days after surgery and cosmetic appearance summary score at a minimum of 4 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: A two-arm 1 : 1 parallel-group open multicentre superiority RCT was performed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 451 children presenting with a suspected nail bed injury were recruited between July 2018 and July 2019; 224 were allocated to the nail-discarded arm, and 227 to the nail-replaced arm.

Harms.evidence: There was no difference in the number of surgical-site infections at around 7 days between the two interventions.
